conclusion: Ensure optical signal is totally internally reflected within the optical fiber.
Total internal reflection occurs when light travels from a medium with higher refractive index to lower refractive index, and angle of incidence is greater than critical angle.
Given refractive index of optical fiber (N), diameter of optical fiber cross-section (D), and optical fiber bent into semicircle with turning radius (r).
Critical angle (θc) for total internal reflection is given by θc = arcsin(1/N).
For total internal reflection, angle of incidence (θi) must be greater than critical angle (θc).
Light travels through fiber and bends along semicircular path; maximum angle of incidence occurs where light is tangent to semicircle.
Light path forms a triangle with radius (r) and diameter (D).
Using semicircle geometry, angle of incidence (θi) at critical point is related to radius (r) by sin(θi) = D/2r.
For total internal reflection, sin(θi) > sin(θc).
Solving for r gives r > D/2 * N.
Turning radius (r) of central axis of optical fiber should be not less than r ≥ D/2 * N.
This ensures light is totally internally reflected within the optical fiber.
